=== Fonts ===
==== Change Font Size in Interface ====
To change the font that window text appears in, you will have to look in different places for different windows.  
1. Use the LXDE preference menu to Open "Openbox Configuration Manager" in 12.04 and later, click "Appearance" tab.
2. Right click on the bottom panel and select "Panel Settings" to change the panel font size
3. Use the LXDE preferences menu to open "Customize Look and Feel".  Click the Widget tab.
4. Change the taskbar font size <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Lubuntu/Windows#Changing_Font_Size | here.]]</nowiki>

------
==== Install and view fonts in Lubuntu ====
On <nowiki>[[http://wiki.ubuntu.com/Fonts | this page]]</nowiki> it instructs you to press <code>alt-f2</code> and type<<BR>>
<code>gksu nautilus /usr/share/fonts/truetype</code> <<BR>>
But, for Lubuntu which has a different file manager, PCManFM, you should press <code>alt-f2</code> and type <<BR>>
<code>gksu pcmanfm /usr/share/fonts/truetype</code><<BR>>

The window that opens is a place for you to place your font files into.  You will need to unpackage them to place each .ttf or .otf file in here.<<BR>>
(Optional) afterwards, do this command:<<BR>>
<code>sudo fc-cache -f -v</code><<BR>>
-----
Alternatively, you can install a tool to install or view fonts in Lubuntu, install this package: <<BR>>
gnome-font-viewer
-----
Synaptic Package Manager has a convient listing of fonts you can install from the trusted repositories in section on the left sidebar and lists fonts.

=== Sound ===
Sound should work in Lubuntu automatically.  Although not included in Lubuntu, Pulseaudio can be installed if you need it.<<BR>>
Unless you have Pulseaudio, you will have to select audio devices with <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Sound | asound]]</nowiki>, and control volume with the "Volume Control" panel applet or the alsamixer command from the command line.<<BR>>
Read about alsamixer <nowiki>[[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alsamixer | here]]</nowiki> or <nowiki>[[http://alsa.opensrc.org/Alsamixer | here.]]</nowiki> People with no sound should look <nowiki>[[ SoundTroubleshootingProcedure | here.]]</nowiki> Most Lubuntu sound troubleshooting is done in the command line.<<BR>>
==== Sound Preferences ====
There is no "Sound Preferences" in Lubuntu, but there is in Ubuntu.<<BR>>
==== Playing Audio CDs ====
Insert the audio CD.  It should mount automatically.  At this point you can play the CD by opening with PCManFM and opening audio tracks with Mplayer, or you can open audacious and choose "Play CD" from the Audacious menu.
==== Testing Sounds with Sound Recorder ====
Looking for a GUI sound recorder application to test your microphone or headset?
Install this software package:<<BR>>
gnome-media<<BR>>
or install gnome-media without pulseaudio with:
<pre>
sudo apt-get install gnome-media --no-install-recommends
</pre>
==== Change Default Sound card ====
If you would like to change the default sound card: look <nowiki>[[http://www.seehuhn.de/pages/alsa | here.]]</nowiki><<BR>>

==== Checking Pulseaudio ====
You may find packages with 'pulse' in their name on your system.  to check if pulseaudio is currently running do:

pgrep -l pulseaudio

which will list a process named 'pulseaudio' if it is running, or not list it, if it is not.

If you would like install the pulseaudio layer onto Lubuntu, please see <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PulseAudio | Pulse Audio]]</nowiki>
Pulseaudio can help if you're having difficulty configuring USB headphones, Skype, or need to increase volume past 100%

== Applications ==

There may come a time, especially when trouble-shooting, when you need to launch any of the applications listed below from the command line rather than by selecting it from a menu. Here's a small one-liner to generate a list of application names and their associated commands. This one-liner will cover only those programs that have `.desktop` files in `/usr/share/applications`:
<pre>
sed -nrs '/^\[Desktop Entry\]/d;/^(\[|Name=|Exec=)/p;${g;p}' /usr/share/applications/*.desktop > ~/Desktop/Names-n-Commands.txt
</pre>
When you run the command given above from a terminal, it will create a list of application names paired with their respective commands in a text file called `Names-n-Commands.txt` and this file will be on your Desktop for ready reference.

== Maintenance ==
=== Check Hardware ===
<nowiki>[[Smartmontools#Testing_a_Drive]]</nowiki> and http://systester.sourceforge.net/ to test your CPU.  Booting into GRUB or the LiveCD, there is a RAM tester. The gnome-disks program also graphically can detect SMART data for self test on hard and solid state drives from the settings button in the upper right corner. This will even work in the live session. 
=== Lost Password ===
When you installed Lubuntu, you should have given it a supervisor password for the default user.  <nowiki>[[  http:--www.psychocats.net-ubuntu-resetpassword- | here]]</nowiki> is how to recover the password if you have forgotten it.<<BR>>
=== Share Files and Folders ===
Would you like to share files on your network?  Lubuntu's <nowiki>[[Lubuntu-PCManFM]]</nowiki> can easily connect to your Microsoft Windows® file shares.  If you need to share files from Lubuntu, you should install and configure <nowiki>[[Samba]]</nowiki> or <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/SettingUpNFSHowTo | NFS]]</nowiki> from the command line.<<BR>> 
Let me say it again, if you want to share your Lubuntu files with Win7, please follow the <nowiki>[[Samba-SambaServerGuide | Samba Server Guide]]</nowiki>
